title: Stocks Open Mixed; Oil Drops; Quarterly results are due from Netflix and IBM after markets close
text:
Roblox shares fell 4% premarket after Goldman Sachs downgraded the stock, cutting its price target for the videogame company by more than half. Johnson & Johnson edged down 0.4% after the pharmaceutical firm cut its guidance for the year.

American Campus Communities jumped 13% premarket after The Wall Street Journal reported that Blackstone is buying the student-housing owner in a deal valued at $12.8 billion.

Lockheed Martin fell 2.1% after the defense contractor reported sales that were worse than analysts were expecting. Travelers Cos. fell 2.3% after reporting earnings that showed a rise in first-quarter profits and lifted its dividend. Plug Power rose 6.9% after the alternative energy company said it had struck a deal with Walmart to supply the retailer with hydrogen.

Netflix and IBM are expected to release earnings after markets close.

Concerns about inflation—which has soared to multidecade highs—and how central banks might respond have dominated investors' thinking for months, but so far corporate finances have been protected as firms have largely managed to pass higher costs on to consumers. Investors say they are expecting earnings to moderate this quarter as it becomes harder for companies to continue raising consumer costs.

"The longer prices stay high, the longer the war in Ukraine continues, the higher likelihood that something has to give. Corporations cannot continue to pass on input costs forever," said Brian O'Reilly, head of market strategy at Mediolanum International Funds. "There has to be a tipping point."

In bond markets, the yield on the 10-year Treasury note rose further after setting its highest closing level since December 2018. The yield on the benchmark bond rose to 2.909% from 2.861% on Monday. The yield on the 30-year note rose to 2.984% from 2.951% on Monday, taking it within sight of 3% for the first time in three years.

Bond yields rise as prices fall, and investors have been selling bonds on expectations of high inflation and interest-rate increases from the Federal Reserve.

"Fixed income has been a particular point of pain. This is the worst bear market in bonds we've seen in a generation," Mr. O'Reilly said.

In commodity markets, Brent crude, the international oil benchmark, fell 2.6% to $110.25 a barrel. Gold prices declined 0.3%.

Overseas, the Stoxx Europe 600 dropped 1.2% as household goods companies and healthcare stocks slumped.

In Asia, stock markets were mixed. The Nikkei 225 rose 0.7% as Japan's yen fell to a 20-year low against the dollar. In Hong Kong, the Hang Seng Index fell 2.3%, dragged lower by technology firms. The Shanghai Composite Index lost 0.1%.
